review_blob: On cask in Windmill Pub, Brixton. Hazy golden colour with a mdeium head which dissipates to nothing. Nose is grainy, grassy hops, slight touch of sour crispness, pale malts. Taste is grassy, straw, slight sour bitterness, barley grain sweetness.

On keg at the Brixton Windmill Bread & Beer Festival. Very much in the mould of the original American big hoppy IPA. Orange to chestnut brown, little hazy. Nose is big bitter hop, citrousy rind, grapefruit rind, crystal malt, caramel, pine. Taste is hoppy, citrus rind, lemon and grapefruit rind, caramel, crystal malt, some breadiness, pine.

On keg in Craft Beer Co Brixton. Hazy bright yellow to golden lager with a medium foam head which dissipates to the rim quickly. Nose is lemon, slight sour, pale grains, slight sulphur. Taste is dry, citric acidic, light bitter, light pale malt, slight sherbet try. Couple of notches above a macro lager but fresher and with more flavour.

Bottle from Dranken Geers. Bright opaque golden amber in the glass with a medium to large soft white foam head. Nose is delightful. Big, fruity, floral, perfumed, caramel, toffee, bready, funky, creamy, floral blossom, hints of citrous peel, grass, honey. Lots of sweetness, with a stunning floral yeasty nose. Taste is citrous bitter, lemon, grapefruit and lime peel, caramel and toffee, grassy, straw, toasted grains. So fragrant and full of flavoured. Amazing beer. Nice bitterness on the finish balanced with sweet caramel notes and big big perfumed fragrant Belgian yeast.

Stunned that I have not rated this. Bottle of the 2011. When I take off the wire case on the cork the cork just pops out and hits the roof. Its in perfect condition though. Opaque deep red, with a medium white head which dissipates to a thin head which stays throughout. Nose is tart and sour but suffused with sweet fruity cherry. Acid and sour nose but the fruit really come through. Taste is moderately tart and sour, balanced out with a very natural cherry sweetness, moderately acidic and sweet on the tongue. Perfect balance for a kriek. Slight funkiness but Im loving the fruit in this.
UPDATED: APR 22, 2016

Bottle of the 2015 from the Great British Beer festival 2015. Third beer from this brewery and each one has been magnificent. This is listed as an old ale, but its profile feels more towards a barley wine. Colour is murky, rich reddish orange. Deep rusty with off white beige head which dissipates to nothing. Nose is sublime. Big fruity, particularly dried apricot, stewed plum, prune, pear, barley sugar, ripe fruit. What a joy to have a big American ale which is not cloying with pine and citrous fruit. Taste is ripe fruit, prune, plums, apricot, slight citrous bitterness, tangy fruit, raisins and sultanas, fruit bready. Deep, rich fruity beer. Stunning. Congratulations to the brewers. This is excellence.

On tap in Cantillon brewery. Clear pale amber, urine looking beer with almost no carbonation. Nose is sweaty, barnyard, very slightly sour, urine, funky, lightly citrousy. Taste is flat, uncarbonated, sweaty, dry, light fruity citrous, barnyard, slightly cheesy.

On draft in Moeder Lambic Fontainas. Clear red beer, thin white head. Nose is floral, rose water, barley sugar, strawberry, toffee and caramel. Taste is sweet, honeyish, barley sugar, toffee, floral, roses. Its quite sweet, just short of cloying, syrupy.

Bottle from Berkhamsted Beer Shop. Clear chestnut light brown beer with a thin white head Nose is muddy, earthy, leaves, fresh baked ginger snap biscuits, bready. Taste is fairly unremarkable. Little ginger snap, astringent English earthy hop, slight bitterness, bready, nutty, slightly toasty malt. Like a pasteurised standard English bitter.

Keg in CBC Covent Garden. Clear rusty orange beer with a thin white head. This basically has the clean lines of a lager, but with the tropical and citrous fruitiness and pine of an IPA. Perfectly quaffable but its not really a combination that does much for me. I either want big punchy fruit from an IPA or grassy dry clean lines from a lager.
beer_name: Orbit / The Craft Beer Co Werk

review_blob: On tap in Moeder Lambic Fontainas. Bright hazy yellow amber, with a large soft fluffy white foam head. Nose is yeasty, little sulphur, lemon juice, lemon peel, spicy, little grain husky, lightly bitter. Taste is light, lemony and refreshing. Really nice beer.
beer_name: De la Senne Band of Brothers

review_blob: UPDATED: APR 10, 2016
beer_name: De la Senne / Thiriez Birthday Session

review_blob: Clear blonde beer with a big white foam head. Nose is grassy, straw, bubblegum, green hops, menthol, light grains. Taste is bubblegum, light grains, menthol, grassy, straw, floral.

On draft at the BIFFF festival in Brussels. Cloudy bright Amber beer, with a soft white head. Nose is lemon citrous, grassy, hoppy, with some orange and hop, light spice and light fruity yeast esters. Citrous orange and lemon, light grass, hop and citrous on taste. Not punchy but perfectly drinkable.

Bottle at the brewery. Hazy pink with golden hues, no head whatsoever. Nose is peppery, black and white pepper, tart and sour, some mustiness and horseblanket, slight grape maybe, more just subtle berry fruit. Pepper is huge. Taste is moderate to high tartness and fruitiness, more of the fruit and slight red vinous, some of the pepper but more subtle than the nose. Little sherbet like effervescence.

On tap in Delirium Cafe, Brussels. Clear blonde beer with a medium to large foam head. Nose is hop forward, green hops, grassy, grain husky, lemon. Like De Ranke Xx. Taste is acidic green floral hops, grain husky.

25cl draft version in Moeder Lambic, Brussels. Golden orange, clear with a large soft white fluffy foam head. Nose is stunning. Big orange blossom, bubblegum, toasted grains, grain chaff, caramel, Manuka honey, very floral. Taste is fragrant orange blossom, caramel, floral, orange peel, toasted grains, honey.

Keg at CBC Craft #100. Opaque very dark brown beer. Nose is very sweet sugary toffee, salty Marmite, yeast extract, brown sugar, roasted malt, vanilla, creme caramel, dark fruit, chocolate. On the taste its really dominated by the salty Marmite/yeast extract flavour, which I am really not a fan of. Mouthfeel is thick and oily, black treacle sweetness with savoury molasses or Marmite.

On keg in King & Co. This was a light chestnut brown beer with an off white head. Nose was nutty, citrous, caramel, fruity, grassy. Taste had rather a lot going on. Toasty grains and malt, caramel, nutty but with some citrous, fruit, slight tartness, hay and grassy, earthy hops. Not quite all working smoothly together, but perfectly drinkable.

Bottle from The Beer Shop Berkhamsted. Pours golden, touch of haze, medium white head. Nose is wheaty, straw, bread dough, slight tartness, slight citrous, toasty grains. Taste is citrous acidic, grain chaff, wheat, little citric acidic tartness.

Half on keg in King & Co. This is a hangover from their meet the Brewer night. Clear orange to chestnut brown, thin white foam head. Nose is big toffee and barley sugar, earthy hop, little grassy and hay. Taste is nice combo of grassy, hay and then caramel and toffee. Really good.

Bottle from Kris Wines. Dark golden amber to orange/brown, hazy, huge foam white head. Nose is toasted malt, big herbal, bay leaf, coriander, banana, caramel, fresh cut grass, boiled vegetables, stewed plums. The herbal grassy stuff is a bit odd, but its got a lot of aroma. Taste, is banana ester, caramel, clove, cola, herbal. Body is a little thin but its drinkable.

On cask at King & Co. meet the brewer event. Opaque very dark brown to black colour with a foamy tan head. Nose is chocolatey, lactic milky, little creamy, roasted malt, little grain chaff, malty sweetness. Taste is sweet chocolate, milk chocolate, lactic milky and creaminess, slight touch of dark fruit. Its sweet but very drinkable, with enough roasted flavours balancing the sweetness. Very nice.
beer_name: Little Beer Little Smooth Milk Stout

review_blob: On keg at CBC #100. Pale almost clear yellow to amber, white head. Nose is intensely acidic. Nose is citrus acid, lemons, grapefruit, bit musty, grassy, lychee, apricot, but very very tart. Taste is massively tart and sour with a very bitter acidic bite. Lemon peel, citric acid, musty, tangy, citrus. I love my lambics but this is a bit too sour and acidic.
beer_name: High Water Central Valley Breakfast Sour

review_blob: On keg at CBC #100. Clear pale amber with a white head. Nose is toasted grain, lightly grassy, straw, little fruity and citrousy, dry lager yeast. Taste is slight fruity citrous, floral, grassy, citrous, biscuit malt, slightly toasty grains, dry lager yeast. Slightly fruity lager.

Cask, gravity dispense, #Craft100. Clear amber with hints of orange, light white foam head. Nose is huge tropical fruit: pineapple, guava, mango, passion fruit, citrous fruit, a veritable fruit salad. Also some grass and a little grain husk. Taste is slightly more muted, but lots of fruit, pineapple, quite a lot of peach, guava, hints of menthol, little grainy.

Cask pint in Royal Oak, Borough. Pours opaque black with dark brown and reddish tinges. Off white/ beige light thin foam head. Nose is the Harveys house yeast aroma of fruit, rhubarb, mushroom, menthol, and then dark malts, roasted malt, black coffee, dark chocolate. Taste is nice combination of the Harveys fruity yeast and dark and roasted malt, dark chocolate, black coffee, bit of menthol. Finish is a lingering dry and burnt malts on the back of the tongue. Body is quite full.

Bottle of the 2010 from Dranken Pauwels. Pours opaque very dark brown to black with a beige head which thins very quickly. Nose is big, fruity, rich and fragrant. Chocolate chip cookie dough, banana, ripe fruit, plum and prune, cocoa, dark chocolate, fruit cake, doughy bread, cinnamon. I could go on. How long have you got? Black grape, caramel, raisin. Taste is banana-ery ester, dark fruit, prune, stewed plum and peach, dark chocolate, little bit of aged second fill wood (something like port or little fortified vinous), little acidic on the palate. Slighted bitter roasted malt on finish which dries quickly. The nose on this is stunning but the finish is short and abrupt so this may be weakening in the bottle. As it warms up theres some cherry and Bakewell tart, almond on the finish too.

750ml bottle from Hop Burns & Black. Pours rich rusty orange, some haze, white foam head. Nose is strong elderflower musky fruit, white apple, apple blossom, little cheese rind and barnyard, hint of sulphur, acidic and tartness. Taste is big sour and acidic tart, then with elderflower earthiness, sweet fruitiness, white apple, floral. Tartness is very bold and leading but it works with the elderflower cordial sweetness to balance it. I love elderflower so this is a dream come true for me. Two of my favourite things: elderflower and lambic. Any tarter though and it might be too sour.

Bottle from Hop Burns & Black. Pours opaque very dark brown to black with an brown foam head. Nose is rich coffee, cocoa, dark chocolate, quite minerally, a fair amount of burnt malts. Taste is roasted burnt malts, coffee grains, quite heavy minerals, dark chocoalte, cocoa dust, dry on the palate. Maybe a hint of salt but not getting any of the oyster.

Bottle from Fenwicks, Newcastle. Chestnut brown to ruby red clear beer, with a slight white head. Nose is brown bread, slightly burnt toast, earthy, nutty English hop, slight hint of cocoa or coffee, but its fairly dull. Taste is light watery, brown bread, toasted malt, slight earthy fruity hop. This needs a bit more of everything.

Half on keg at King & Co Meet the Brewer event. Hazy bright light amber beer with a soft medium foam head. Nose is citrousy, acidic, bitter, lemon, slight sulphury minerals. Taste is dry bitter citrousy hop, lemon, lemon rind, acidic, citrous pithy, light grass, light spice.

Half on keg in King & Co at meet the brewer event. Clear light golden amber, with a medium white foam head which thins. Nose is light grassy, slightly toasty malt, slight citrousy, a nice fruitiness. Taste is clean, dry, grassy, hay, slightly toasty malt and some nice fruitiness. Nice to get a bit more flavour from a style that doesnt usually offer up much.

Half on keg in King & Co Meet the Brewer night. Hazy light bright amber beer with a nice medium creamy foam head. Nose is yeasty, lemon, lime zest, citrousy, a touch of wit bier yeast aromatic, light hay, slight sour acidic. Taste is butter, slight sour citrous, lime peel, lemon, touch of orange, grassy, hay. Very refreshing and packed full of zesty citrous.

Bottle from Market Row Wines. Pours hazy rusty orange, big white head which dissipates to nothing quickly. Nose is is big pine, grapefruit peel, citrousy bitter, orange pithy citrous. Big American IPA notes. Not getting classic Brett character. Hints of earthiness. Taste is big bitter hop, pine, bitter grapefruit and lime rind, softer pithy orange, flinty minerals. Im a bit jaded by big hoppy beers so this aint really ticking the boxes for me. Been there, done that. Mouthfeel is less carbonated, softer. Giving it a 3.4 but feel like Im going through the motions.

Bottle from High St Kensington Wholefoods. Colour is amber with abit of rusty orange, foam white head. Nose is pine, citrous grapefruit, caramel, grassy. Its a fairly standard hoppy, bitter, pine American IPA. Taste is all of the above plus a hints of crystal malt character.

Bottle from Kris Wines. Pours almost clear golden amber. The moment I nose this I know its special. Has an aroma like aged Tripel Karmeliet. Big floral, fragrant, orange blossom, orange citrous, yuzu, and underneath theres some bready, brioche malt. Stunningly fragrant nose. Taste is little oily like a good white burgundy, soft carbnation, lots of orange blossom, orange citrous, lots of floral perfume, acidic bitterness, slight white vinous, little dried coriander, dry grassiness.

Bottle from Lidl. 500ml. Colour is surprisingly ale like rather than dark and opaque. Clear dark red to chesnut brown with a thin beige to off white head. Nose is burnt and toasty malts, ale fruity. Taste is burnt malts, earthy hop, toasted malt, chocolate malt, burnt malt, burnt bitterness, charcoal, dry-ish mouth feel. Curious that such a light clear looking ale has so much burnt and toasty malt.
beer_name: Lidl Hatherwood The Purple Panther Porter No.5

review_blob: On keg in King & Co, Clapham. Almost clear reddish rusty beer with a thin white head. Nose is red berry fruit, light citrus, light burnt malts and charcoal. Taste is earthy and citrus malts, toasted grains, slight pine kernel, acidic hop. Slight burnt charcoal on the finish but its hidden.

Bottle from Sainsburys. Pours pretty standard looking chestnut brown ale, clear, big beige head which dissipates to very thin. Nose is caramel, nutty, grassy, slight coffee-ish, bready, rye bread, toasted grains, earthy and little hop astringent. Taste is caramel, earthy hop, hop bitterness, slight citrous bitter, toasted grains, slight dry grassiness.
UPDATED: FEB 16, 2016

Bottle from Dranken Geers. Dated Jan 2015. Bottle opens easily with no pop, and a lot of the gas has gone. Beautiful reddish glow to this delicate looking orange beer, very thin head, only lightly effervescent. Nose is leather, sour, apple vinegar, apple cider, white and oxidised flesh apple, light horseblanket. Not massively funky or farmyardy, but really nice apple and cider fruit with leather. Taste is dry, fruity apple cider, sour apple vinegar, white wine vinegar, tart, citric acid, leather, lactobacillus sour, some tannin like substance on the tongue.

Bottle from Dranken Geers near Ghent. Colour is rich golden orange, bright and fresh with a big creamy white head. Nose is orange, grapefruit and lemon citrous, toffee, creamy, citrous pith, earthy, light farmyard. straw, cereal chaff, fresh cut grass . Taste is soft citrous fruit, grassy, straw, slight farmyard, barley chaff, nettle. Soft fruits, green grassy and bitter.

Bottle from a friend. Colour was very hazy yellow amber with a thin bubbly head. Nose is classic simcoe. Not my favourite hop. Sharp citrous, flinty, hard bitter hop. Taste is minerally, hard grapefruit and lemon citrous, flinty. I just find it too bitter and minerally hard. No soft fruit in this.

Pint on cask in the Prince of Wales Faether on Warren St, London. this was in great condition. Ill be coming back to this pub. Nose is dusty chocolate, cereal chaff, some sulphur, the so-called Burton snatch, very biscuity malt. taste is malty, biscuit malt, slight citrous, digestive biscuit.

Bottle from Wholefoods High Street Kensington. Colour is almost clear, deep red to chestnut brown with a off white to beige head which stays. Nose is fruity, strawberry, light Brett, caramel, bubblegum, toasted grains, light spice, light clove. Elements of a quad but with delicate fruit. Strawberry fruit is totally dominating. Really nice and unexpected. Taste is lightly hoppy, strawberry, light Brett yeast, bubblegum, toasted grains, dryish yeast, little acidic hop, little earthiness, candy sugar. Strawberry fruit flavour is delightful. This is a really subtle mixture of flavours with the berry fruit dominating. Delightful beer.

Bottle from Bottledog. Looks beautiful. Opaque very dark brown, brown tan head, oily and a little thick in the glass. Nose wrong foots me slightly. Big liquorice, molasses, salty, yeast extract, roasted malt, black sugar., black coffee, aged wood barrel. I was expecting lots of sweetness and vanilla but its quite subtle dark chocolate, vanilla. Taste is yeast extract, liquorice, salty, molasses, black coffee lots of roasted malt, dryish but also black sugar sweetness and vanilla and aged wood barrel. Its good but not blowing me away.

Can from Hop Burns & Black. Opaque very dark to black, tan head. Nose is very dry black coffee, burnt malts, dark dried fruit, plum, milk chocolate, dark chocolate, milky. Fruity and coffee. Taste is quite light bodied, burnt roasted malts, dry coffee. Lacks a bit of body to pull this off, but theres some nice interesting fruity plum and coffee combination.

Bottle of the 2014, from Dranken Pauwels. Slightly hazy reddish chestnut brown with an off white head. Nose is bit of yeast extract, slight oxidization, toasted malt, earthy, grassy hop, straw, toast, red fruit. Marmite yeast extract is dominating a bit. Taste is quite hoppy, grassy, pine, with lots of toasted malt and yeast extract. On the finish Im getting some fruit coming through. Bit of red berry fruit, maybe dried apricot and then slight pine and menthol. Its got quite a tang to it.
